item.title: Data Deep Dive: Oklahoma County Detention Center
item.description: “Data Deep Dive” posts provide a broad overview of a particular dataset, policy area, or problem. This one covers Open Justice Oklahoma’s Oklahoma county jail data, which includes information on the population, bookings, releases, etc. at the Oklahoma County Detention Center (OCDC) in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma. The Oklahoma County Detention Center # Located in Oklahoma City, the Oklahoma County Detention Center (OCDC) is the biggest jail in the state. On an typical day, an average of around 1,500-1,600 people are held inside, most of them awaiting their day in court.

Stat Spotlight: Eviction Filings Are Soaring in Oklahoma County
item.description: Figure 1: Eviction filings are on the rise. Eviction filings across the state have been rising steadily since the onset of the COVID-19 Pandemic, despite eviction moratoriums and assistance programs aimed at preventing people from losing their homes due to the crisis. In Oklahoma County in particular, though, it seems that the dam may have finally broken – in February of 2022, Oklahoma County landlords filed 2,200 eviction cases, which is more than any month on record.

item.title: About Open Justice Oklahoma
item.description: What is OJO? # Open Justice Oklahoma (OJO) is a criminal justice research nonprofit that seeks to improve understanding of our justice system through analysis of public data. Working closely with justice system stakeholders and advocates, we use cutting-edge methods to identify problems, craft solutions, and measure reform outcomes. Our goal is to provide all Oklahomans with a more complete understanding of how our justice system operates and how we can use it to reduce crime, protect public safety, and improve rehabilitation.

item.title: OJO Research Team
item.description: Ryan Gentzler – Research Director # Ryan Gentzler is the Director of Open Justice Oklahoma. For over two years, Ryan served as a Policy Analyst focused on criminal justice at Oklahoma Policy Institute, where he was responsible for research on topics including sentencing, incarceration, court fines and fees, and pretrial detention. Open Justice Oklahoma grew out of Ryan’s groundbreaking analysis of court records, which was used to inform critical policy debates.
